Award.AwardTitle: NSF-CPS-Medium: Collaborative Research: Design and development of a cybernetic exoskeleton for hand-wrist rehabilitation through the integration of human passive properties

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotic devices are excellent candidates for delivering repetitive and intensive practice that can restore functional use of the upper limbs, even years after a stroke. Rehabilitation of the wrist and hand in particular are critical for recovery of function, since hands are the primary interface with the world. However, robotic devices that focus on hand rehabilitation are limited due to excessive cost, complexity, or limited functionality. A design and control strategy for such devices that bridges this gap is critical. The goals of the research effort are to analyze the properties and role of passive dynamics, defined by joint stiffness and damping, in the human hand and wrist during grasping and manipulation, and then mimic such properties in a wrist-hand exoskeleton for stroke rehabilitation. The project will culminate with device testing in collaboration with rehabilitation clinicians.

A significant problem in robotic rehabilitation is how to provide assisted movement to the multiple degrees of freedom of the hand in order to restore motor coordination and function, with a system that is practical for deployment in a clinical environment. Armed with a clearer understanding of the mechanisms underlying passive dynamics and control of systems exhibiting such behavior, this project will inform the design of more effective wrist/hand rehabilitation devices that are feasible for clinical use. In addition, the proposed project will create a unique interdisciplinary environment enabling education, training, and co-advising of graduate students, undergraduate research, and significant and targeted outreach activities to underrepresented groups in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the research effort were to analyze the properties and role of passive dynamics, defined by joint stiffness and damping, in the human hand and wrist during grasping and manipulation, and then mimic such properties in a wrist-hand exoskeleton for stroke rehabilitation. This project has informed the design of more effective wrist/hand rehabilitation devices that are feasible for clinical use. In addition, the proposed project created a unique interdisciplinary environment enabling education, training, and co-advising of graduate students, undergraduate research, and significant and targeted outreach activities to underrepresented groups in science and engineering. These aspects address the broader impacts of the research effort.

A significant majority of stroke survivors suffer from upper limb paresis, yet only a fraction of these individuals gain full motor recovery with conventional treatments in the year following stroke. Thus, continued rehabilitation of the impaired limb is needed. Robotic devices are excellent candidates for delivering repetitive and intensive practice that can facilitate motor recovery in chronic stroke cases, even several years after the injury. Rehabilitation of the wrist and hand in particular are critical for recovery of functional movement which enables execution of activities of daily living (ADLs) and allow for independent living after stroke. However, robotic devices that focus on hand rehabilitation are limited due to either excessive cost and complexity, or limited functionality. A design and control strategy for such devices that bridges this gap is critical.

In order to develop robotic devices that facilitate the range of hand movements that are characteristic of ADLs, devices must allow for multiple degrees of freedom and natural control. In this integrated research effort, we proposed that rehabilitation devices for the upper extremities, especially the wrist and hand, must be designed to match and leverage passive dynamic properties, such as those that exist in the human hand.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research stems from the analytical basis for modeling of passive dynamic properties and control mechanisms, and how to integrate the mechanical design of wrist/hand exoskeletons with control for close physical coupling between machine and man. 

Outcomes 

 The team completed the following activities during the life of the award, all contributing to the goal of an integrated wrist-hand exoskeleton for robot-assisted stroke rehabilitation. 

  • Development of UT Hand Exoskeleton Ver 1.0 (includes design optimization, incorporation of additive manufacturing techniques, controller development for assist-as-needed and torque control, and autocalibration for accurate joint angle sensing)
  • Novel intent-detection algorithms for controlling exoskeletons, including an EMG-base exoskeleton for assisting SCI patients’ daily activities
  • A Novel Framework for Optimizing Motor (Re)-learning with a Robotic Exoskeleton
  • REDAPT: Integration of UT hand exoskeleton and new OpenWrist wrist exoskeleton hardware developed at Rice that features improved range of motion and force output
  • Assessment of impact of robotic devices on movement coordination and smoothness

 PI and team interactions: In order to advance the collaborations between the UT and Rice groups, the teams conducted bimonthly Skype meetings and shared materials via cloud-based tools. Additionally, noting the importance of face-to-face interactions, we held a number of meetings at the two project locations and at conferences. 

Outreach: The ReNeu and MAHI labs conducted a number of outreach activities aimed at broadening participation in STEM fields. Activities included laboratory tours for K-12 and teachers, lectures, and graduate student mentoring of high school students. 

Education: The PI’s completed curricular development on haptic paddles (Rice) and a robot mechanism design course (UT). Graduate and undergraduate students were engaged with the research effort throughout the life of the grant.

 Synergistic activities: PI O’Malley collaborated with National Instruments and participated in an online NSF workshop to disseminate haptic paddle educational experiences. PI Deshpande collaborated with faculty members at UT to initiate a new research group in Clinically Assisted Rehabilitation Engineering (CARE).
